description: Originally US English; first attested with the meaning “energy” in 1842, and with the meaning “semen” in c.1888. For semantic development, compare spunk. Perhaps ultimately from British dialect chissom, a shoot or sprout.
Unlikely to be related to Arabic جِسْم‎ (jism, “body”) (or its Hindi derivative जिस्म (jisma)).

examples: “ […]  the girls in blue movies rub their faces in jism”
